title: Was BoJack Horseman cancelled by Netflix?
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Last week’s announcement about the forthcoming new season of BoJack Horseman was met with joy and despair in equal measure.

The sixth season of the popular animated Netflix show will also be its last, with the final instalment being split into two parts: the first will arrive on 25 October before the second block of episodes drops on 31 January 2020.

But BoJack voice star Aaron Paul threw in something of a plot twist for disheartened fans shortly after that official announcement, tweeting: ‘Sadly Netflix thought it was time to close the curtains and so here we are.’

We had a wonderful time making Bojack. Couldn’t be more proud. Fell in love with these characters just like everyone else did but sadly Netflix thought it was time to close the curtains and so here we are. They gave us a home for 6 beautiful years. Nothing we could do about it. — Aaron Paul (@aaronpaul_8) September 27, 2019

Advertisement

Advertisement

Paul’s choice of words has subsequently fuelled fan rumours that Netflix actually cancelled BoJack, despite reports that creator Raphael Bob-Waksberg intended to end the show after its sixth season.

Netflix haven’t commented on the speculation, nor have they supplied any official explanation for why BoJack is ending after six years on the streaming platform.

Further rumours about the end of the show have since gathered pace, with some fans linking developments at the show’s animation and production studio, The Tornante Company’s ShadowMachine, to the decision to bring BoJack to an end.

The artistic crew successfully negotiated a deal to unionise with The Animation Guild (TAG) back in June, a goal they had reportedly been seeking ever since production began on the first season of BoJack back in 2014.

The deal ensured that the BoJack crew at ShadowMachine receive a minimum wage, and employer-paid retirement and health benefits.

They did it! The #BoJackHorseman crew ratified a new contract today and has unionized with #TheAnimationGuild! Congrats to this crew for their hard work and dedication and thank you for all the support from fellow artists and fans! #unionizebojack #valueartists #artistsunited pic.twitter.com/Us2Yc38CUW — The Animation Guild (@animationguild) June 21, 2019

‘This crew was organised, determined, and showed their resolve and solidarity throughout the process,’ Jason MacLeod, a TAG representative, said in the summer.

‘We congratulate the crew on this result and are glad to see that this successful show will be a union production going forward.’

Regular BoJack director Aaron Long has since moved to clarify that there isn’t a link between the animators’ unionisation and the end of BoJack, emphasising that the decision to bring the show to an end with season six was sealed long before the crew joined TAG.

If it wasn't already set to be the last season, unionizing probably wouldn't have helped… but please just know the Bojack artists didn't kill the show by demanding the same pay as Big Mouth and Paradise PD! — Aaron Long (@aalong64) September 28, 2019

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘Please just know the BoJack artists didn’t kill the show by demanding the same pay as Big Mouth and Paradise PD,’ Long added.

News about the end of BoJack also follows on from the actual cancellation by Netflix of the ShadowMachine-produced Tuca & Bertie, which was executively produced by Bob-Waksberg.

BoJack Horseman returns for part one of season six on 25 October on Netflix.

description: BoJack Horseman's upcoming sixth season will also be its last - and shocked fans have been speculating if Netflix cancelled the show.
